CatDescriptText: Warner Macklin, hotel employee, Bentley Drive and Hubert Teasley, custodian, East Liberty, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?"  Mr. Macklin's answer reads: "He's doing real good work in the South, so he should stay there and continue the good work."  Mr. Teasley's answer reads: "I think he should fight for equality in the South.  I think he's needed more there, because achieving equality there is of vital importance."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Warner Mackline wearing patterned knitted cardigan, arabesque patterned button down collared shirt, and hat, standing in front of window; Portrait of Hubert Teasley wearing checkered button down collared shirt, standing in front of window
